Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar of Trade-marks erred in accepting The Post Office's adoption and use of the MAILSORT mark under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: No direct use of MAILSORT by The Post Office or its licensees in Canada before December 16, 1998
Burden_of_Proof: On Canada Post to demonstrate error in the Registrar's decision
Legal_Rule: Under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Trade-marks Act, a public authority must adopt and use a mark in Canada for it to qualify as an official mark
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied under s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act and s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act)
Procedural_Issue: Application of section 50 of the Act to official marks
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper adoption and use of the MAILSORT mark in Canada
Review_Standard: Judicial review under s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use (or lack thereof) of MAILSORT in Canada prior to December 16, 1998
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, particularly ss. 9(1)(n)(iii), 50, and s. 56; Federal Court Act, s. 18.1
Applicant_Challenge: Canada Post challenged the registration of MAILSORT as an official mark
Court_Result: MAILSORT mark's status as an official mark invalidated
Defendant_Response: The Post Office claimed adoption and use of MAILSORT as an official mark
Remedy_Requested: Invalidation of MAILSORT's registration as an official mark
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and cancellation of the official mark designation
Legal_Provision: s. 9(1)(n)(iii), s. 50, s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act; s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of proper adoption and use in Canada
Applicable_Process: Appeal under s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act and judicial review under s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
